content.raw:
Hi @graffy76 , 
  I recently got sdformat to compile with Visual Studio 2015 and a version of boost with a different layout then the one provided in #!/osrf/sdformat/src/900d9b9475c35862751484bfabc617ce647f5e0c/INSTALL_WIN32.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default . The necessary modifications are part of #!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/296/fix-for-compiling-with-visual-studio-and/diff , but I did not experience any problem such as the one that you are describing. 

My suspect is that for some reason something is going wrong in the generation of the Visual Studio solution. If you could attach the `CMakeCache.txt` present in the build directory of sdformat if could be helpful to understand if something went wrong at the CMake level.
content.html:
Hi @graffy76 , I recently got sdformat to compile with Visual Studio 2015 and a version of boost with a different layout then the one provided in #!/osrf/sdformat/src/900d9b9475c35862751484bfabc617ce647f5e0c/INSTALL_WIN32.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default . The necessary modifications are part of #!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/296/fix-for-compiling-with-visual-studio-and/diff , but I did not experience any problem such as the one that you are describing.

My suspect is that for some reason something is going wrong in the generation of the Visual Studio solution. If you could attach the CMakeCache.txt present in the build directory of sdformat if could be helpful to understand if something went wrong at the CMake level.

content.raw:
Silvio,

Thanks for the response.  I ended up grabbing the latest boost build with VC140 binaries and using that.  In the end, though, the CMake still generated the same error, but this time, referenced 'boost-filesystem-vc140-mt-1_63.lib'!

So it seems more like an architecture issue.  My fix was to roll-my-own VC2015 project and import the SDFormat / TinyXML code.  That successfully built SDFormat as an x64 static lib.

If only I could have that much luck building gazebo...

If you ever try again to use Visual Studio 2015 (perhaps with the updated default, now that #!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/296 has been merged) it would be helpful for understanding the problem if you copied the exact error message and the contents of the `CMakeCache.txt` in the build, thanks!

content.raw: I just reran configure.  Now I'm getting architecture errors.  Is sdformat / gazebo supposed to be compiled for x64 or x86?  It's apparently trying to build x86, but I know the Gazebo tutorial provided boost_1_56_0 x64 libs, which, of course, is what boost_163_0 provides.  I tried reconfiguring for x64 using cmake-gui but no luck...
content.html: I just reran configure. Now I'm getting architecture errors. Is sdformat / gazebo supposed to be compiled for x64 or x86? It's apparently trying to build x86, but I know the Gazebo tutorial provided boost_1_56_0 x64 libs, which, of course, is what boost_163_0 provides. I tried reconfiguring for x64 using cmake-gui but no luck...

content.raw:
The `configure` script present in the `sdformat` source repo is meant to be used only on Visual Studio 2013 and for the x86_64 architecture. The 64 bit compiler are explicitly added to the cmd prompt at point 5 of the installation guide : #!/osrf/sdformat/src/5ee36f97cb763fc856264df9d830e4a19b86576c/INSTALL_WIN32.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default . 

However, if you want to use Visual Studio 2015, you will need to manually configure the project without using the `configure` script. In particular you need to make sure that CMake finds `ignition-math` and `Boost` compiled for the right architecture.
content.html:
The configure script present in the sdformat source repo is meant to be used only on Visual Studio 2013 and for the x86_64 architecture. The 64 bit compiler are explicitly added to the cmd prompt at point 5 of the installation guide : #!/osrf/sdformat/src/5ee36f97cb763fc856264df9d830e4a19b86576c/INSTALL_WIN32.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default .

However, if you want to use Visual Studio 2015, you will need to manually configure the project without using the configure script. In particular you need to make sure that CMake finds ignition-math and Boost compiled for the right architecture.

content.raw:
ok.  I've had some success.  I ran cmake-gui and provided the appropriate paths and configured for the native 2015 win64 compiler.  I've done this before with zero luck.  No idea what went differently this time.

Anyway, then, I tried to build the vs project files.  I encountered the following errors:

1.  The linker couldn't find my boost libs for the sdformat project because the lib path wasn't specified under Project Properties -> Linker -> General -> Additional Library Directories.  This was the issue for both Release and Debug.

2. Also, the build fails for the test components.  It can't find "sdformat.dll":

    Error copying file (if different) from "C:/Users/gazebo/gazebo/sdformat/build/src/sdformat.dll" to "C:/Users/gazebo/gazebo/sdformat/build/test/performance/Debug".

This error is generated for the post build event on the integration and performance tests.

After exploring my build results, I see that sdformat.dll is located in C:\Users\gazebo\gazebo\sdformat\build\src\Debug and that sdformat.lib is located in C:\Users\gazebo\gazebo\sdformat\build\src.

The same goes for ign-math3.dll.  Copying both files back one level fixes the problem.  ALL_BUILD succeeds and INSTALL succeeds.
content.html:
ok. I've had some success. I ran cmake-gui and provided the appropriate paths and configured for the native 2015 win64 compiler. I've done this before with zero luck. No idea what went differently this time.

Anyway, then, I tried to build the vs project files. I encountered the following errors:

  1. The linker couldn't find my boost libs for the sdformat project because the lib path wasn't specified under Project Properties -> Linker -> General -> Additional Library Directories. This was the issue for both Release and Debug.

  2. Also, the build fails for the test components. It can't find "sdformat.dll":

    Error copying file (if different) from "C:/Users/gazebo/gazebo/sdformat/build/src/sdformat.dll" to "C:/Users/gazebo/gazebo/sdformat/build/test/performance/Debug".

This error is generated for the post build event on the integration and performance tests.

After exploring my build results, I see that sdformat.dll is located in C:\Users\gazebo\gazebo\sdformat\build\src\Debug and that sdformat.lib is located in C:\Users\gazebo\gazebo\sdformat\build\src.

The same goes for ign-math3.dll. Copying both files back one level fixes the problem. ALL_BUILD succeeds and INSTALL succeeds.

content.raw:
The error 2. should be fixed in the current `default` after #!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/296 has been merged. 
For the error 1: that is strange, `FindBoost` should set the appropriate property in its out variables such that messing with Visual Studio properties is not necessary. Again, attaching your `CMakeCache.txt` would help in investigating the error.
content.html: The error 2. should be fixed in the current default after #!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/296 has been merged. For the error 1: that is strange, FindBoost should set the appropriate property in its out variables such that messing with Visual Studio properties is not necessary. Again, attaching your CMakeCache.txt would help in investigating the error.

content.raw:
FindBoost did, but they were appended to the library filename itself.  When SDFormat didn't build, I saw that and fixed it, but it was unrelated to the actual problem, it seems.  I just tested with it configured as before (complete filepath in the Linker->Input->Additional Dependencies field) and it linked ok.

I should also mention that error #1 also hit me on  the ignition messages library.  Had to copy ign_msgs_exe back a level from the target build dir in order to get it to compile the proto messages and install.  Should I submit an issue for that?

Anyway, thanks for responding.  Helped me work through some really maddening build issues.
content.html:
FindBoost did, but they were appended to the library filename itself. When SDFormat didn't build, I saw that and fixed it, but it was unrelated to the actual problem, it seems. I just tested with it configured as before (complete filepath in the Linker->Input->Additional Dependencies field) and it linked ok.

I should also mention that error #1 also hit me on the ignition messages library. Had to copy ign_msgs_exe back a level from the target build dir in order to get it to compile the proto messages and install. Should I submit an issue for that?

Anyway, thanks for responding. Helped me work through some really maddening build issues.

content.raw:
> FindBoost did, but they were appended to the library filename itself. When SDFormat didn't build, I saw that and fixed it, but it was unrelated to the actual problem, it seems. I just tested with it configured as before (complete filepath in the Linker->Input->Additional Dependencies field) and it linked ok.

Yes, in general it is always better to avoid modifying the project files generated by CMake, and try to fix any issue directly in the CMake . 

> I should also mention that error #1 also hit me on the ignition messages library. Had to copy ign_msgs_exe back a level from the target build dir in order to get it to compile the proto messages and install. Should I submit an issue for that?

There is already a PR for fixing that in https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/19/fix-hardcoded-binary-location-in-cmake/diff , but it still needs to be reviewed. 

> Anyway, thanks for responding. Helped me work through some really maddening build issues.

As I think you sorted out all your issues, feel free to close the issue, thanks.
content.html:
FindBoost did, but they were appended to the library filename itself. When SDFormat didn't build, I saw that and fixed it, but it was unrelated to the actual problem, it seems. I just tested with it configured as before (complete filepath in the Linker->Input->Additional Dependencies field) and it linked ok.

Yes, in general it is always better to avoid modifying the project files generated by CMake, and try to fix any issue directly in the CMake .

I should also mention that error #1 also hit me on the ignition messages library. Had to copy ign_msgs_exe back a level from the target build dir in order to get it to compile the proto messages and install. Should I submit an issue for that?

There is already a PR for fixing that in https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/19/fix-hardcoded-binary-location-in-cmake/diff , but it still needs to be reviewed.

Anyway, thanks for responding. Helped me work through some really maddening build issues.

As I think you sorted out all your issues, feel free to close the issue, thanks.
